scenario_0.summary: During a peak morning receiving operation, two human workers are jointly responsible for unloading bulk stock from Large Shelf 1, transporting it along the main warehouse aisle to Area 4, and collaboratively performing rapid sorting and initial inspection tasks in Area 4. Both frequently walk the full pathway between Large Shelf 1 (M5–L7) and Area 4 (H17), retracing the robot's fixed navigation route almost entirely. Overflow or defective items are regularly moved together to Area 5, further increasing the overlap along H16–H17. As a result, both workers spend extended periods in close proximity to the robot as it travels between M5 and H17, resulting in the smallest possible average distance between the robot and the workers based on naturally occurring workflow, overlapping task zones, and repeated back-and-forth movement along shared corridors.

scenario_1.summary: During a scheduled inventory cycle count and discrepancy resolution period, Worker 1 is tasked with auditing shelves in Region 2 (Shelf 1–6), repeatedly transporting flagged or miscounted items to Area 4 (H17) for secondary inspection and then returning verified items. Meanwhile, Worker 2 handles bulk packages in Region 1 (Boxes 1–3), frequently transferring items to Area 4 (H17) for staging and cross-verification prior to dispatch or reallocation. Periodically, both workers convene in Area 4 to jointly resolve discrepancies, resulting in overlapping activities and shared movement corridors almost entirely tracing the robot’s fixed route (M5 → H17 and back). This operational flow naturally keeps both workers in close proximity to the robot’s path for extended durations, leading to the smallest possible average distance to the robot, driven by overlapping transport cycles, central staging, and repeated convergence at key processing zones.

scenario_2.summary: During a midday expedited returns reprocessing cycle, Worker 1 repeatedly collects batches of returned items from Large Shelf 2 and Large Shelf 3 (L9–M15), carrying them north through the main warehouse corridor to Area 4 (H17) for detailed inspection and eligibility staging. Worker 2 alternates between Area 4, where relabeling and documentation are performed, and the Shelf 4–6 segment in Region 2 (C16–E22), where approved items are immediately restocked. Both use Area 4 as a central staging/processing hub and often operate in close proximity within its adjacent corridors. The robot, carrying items from Large Shelf 1 (M5) along its fixed path to Area 4 (H17), shares nearly the entire southern and central route corridor with Worker 1, and overlaps frequently at H17 with Worker 2. The cyclical, staggered but converging tasks in Area 4, frequent batch handoffs, and high south-to-north and east-to-west movement cycles result in the robot traveling in extremely close proximity to at least one worker for almost its entire route, minimizing the average human-robot distance due to sustained operational congestion and spatial convergence within required workflow zones.

scenario_3.summary: During an intense late-afternoon cross-docking and just-in-time fulfillment window, Worker 1 continuously transfers bulk restock items from Large Shelf 1 to Area 3 for pre-sorting, then from Area 3 to Area 4 for staging, repeatedly mirroring the robot’s path from M5 to H17 along the main horizontal and vertical corridors. Meanwhile, Worker 2 circulates between Shelf 5/6, the Waste Area, Area 5, and Area 4, replenishing packaging materials, sorting urgent orders, and consolidating dispatch, often traversing the robot’s final and central path segments (I14–H17) and causing recurrent overlap at Area 4. The constant, high-density movement through shared corridors, mutual staging at Area 4, and ongoing item transfer result in the robot’s route being consistently and densely occupied by both workers, ensuring the smallest possible average distance between the robot and humans is achieved solely via realistic convergence of work cycles, operational crossovers, and environmental congestion.

scenario_4.summary: During a surprise afternoon quality control audit and urgent repackaging cycle, both human workers are required to simultaneously retrieve and inspect products from Large Shelf 1 and multiple standard Shelves, using Area 2 and Area 4 as dynamic audit/repack staging zones. Worker 1 repeatedly pulls bulk items from Large Shelf 1 (M5–L7), transporting them to Area 2 (I12–I14) or Area 4 (H17) for inspection and rapid repackaging, and frequently commutes between these zones for cross-checks and workflow maintenance. Worker 2 concurrently audits and relocates parcels between Shelf 3/4, Area 2, and Area 4, performing real-time spot checks, taking defect items to the Waste Area, or staging pass items in Area 5. Both workers cycle repeatedly along the major aisle corridor (L6–K11–I14–H17), with frequent overlap at Area 2 and Area 4, often working side by side or converging at identical or adjacent waypoints. The robot, tasked with autonomously moving bulk repack stock from Large Shelf 1 to Area 4, traverses the same high-congestion corridor, resulting in it being almost constantly near one or both workers. The substantial spatial and timing overlap, driven by urgent quality workflow and intensive use of shared central corridors, results in the robot’s average distance to the closest worker being minimized naturally and persistently throughout its route.

scenario_5.summary: During an end-of-day bulk consolidation and redistribution cycle, two human workers are assigned distinct, yet closely interwoven roles that require them to traverse, occupy, and repeatedly return to the same warehouse corridors and central operational areas as the robot’s fixed route (from M5 at Large Shelf 1 to H17 at Area 4). Worker 1 cycles continuously between Large Shelf 1, Area 2, and Area 4, transporting bulk items for sorting and staging, precisely mirroring the robot’s horizontal and vertical travel path. Worker 2 simultaneously clears overflow from Area 5 to Area 4 and, as space constraints demand, shuttles between Area 4, Area 3, and Area 5, repeatedly crossing or sharing the final segments of the robot’s trajectory. High processing volume forces both workers to coordinate their movement and activities directly along the robot’s route: Worker 1 and Worker 2 frequently converge side-by-side or alternate leapfrogging in central aisles and Area 4, resulting in almost constant human presence along all major waypoints of the robot’s journey. The workflow is driven purely by operational necessity—minimizing the average distance between the robot and the workers naturally, through repeated high-density use of identical or adjacent paths and shared staging zones, with no direct interaction or coordination between humans and the autonomous robot.

scenario_6.summary: During an emergency hazardous material segregating operation, two human workers are redeployed to contain and relocate potentially contaminated stock discovered on Large Shelf 1 and Large Shelf 2. Worker 1 rapidly removes suspect items from Large Shelf 1/2, transporting them northward along the main aisle to Area 4 (H17) for quarantine, documentation, and packing, then detours to Area 2 for containment supplies before returning south. Worker 2 continually shuttles between Area 4 (H17) and the Waste Area (F2–G4), repeatedly transporting cleared/safe items via the central corridor, and periodically returns east through Area 3 and Area 2 for new packing materials or overflow handling. Both workers converge, overlap, and parallel the robot's fixed material transport route (M5 to H17) for nearly the entire journey; high-volume, urgent workflow and shared utilization of aisle and staging space result in both workers, often side-by-side, tracing the robot’s course—especially within K9–K11–J13–I14–H17. The robot, unaffected by direct commands, is brought into constant, minimal-distance proximity with the humans purely via emergent operational overlap, environmental congestion, and shared process cycles throughout the critical incident response cycle.

scenario_7.summary: During a high-volume dispatch preparation overlapping a rolling inventory spot audit, Worker 1 continuously cycles between Large Shelf 1 and Area 4, picking and consolidating urgent outbound dispatch orders, while repeatedly retrieving smaller items from Boxes 2 in Region 1 and returning to Area 4 for staging and packing. At the same time, Worker 2 performs a cross-inventory audit, starting at Area 4, descending to Large Shelf 1 for stock checks and replenishment, then periodically traveling to Area 5 for restock containers before returning to Area 4 for updates and further transfers to Boxes 3. Both workers traverse the same central aisle corridors as the robot’s fixed path (M5 to H17), frequently clustering at Area 4 for processing, sorting, and paperwork. This scenario naturally results in both workers repeatedly operating in immediate proximity to the robot for extended durations, with their converging, cyclical workflows and shared pathway usage minimizing the average human-robot distance solely via legitimate operational demands and emergent high-density occupancy of the core movement corridor—never due to any direct coordination or intentional positioning relative to the robot.

scenario_8.summary: During a high-urgency, just-in-time assembly kitting and replenishment cycle, Worker 1 is responsible for repeatedly picking urgent parts and bulk items from Large Shelf 1, transporting them north along the main central corridor to Area 2 for rapid interim sorting and kit assembly, and then shuttling partial or completed kits to Area 4 for immediate dispatch or further processing. Simultaneously, Worker 2 operates in a line-side coordinating role—cycling between Area 4 and Area 5 for late-stage kit review, then moving incomplete kits or components back to Area 2 or Large Shelf 1 via the same main aisle if shortages or errors are discovered, and then returning along these shared routes after supplementation. Both workers move frequently and dynamically along the robot’s fixed path (M5 to H17), often crossing, leapfrogging, or working in near-identical aisles as operational demands force serial and parallel usage of both Area 2 and Area 4 for processing. The high-frequency, bi-directional, and parallel flows—driven by volatile assembly requirements—result in the robot nearly always being in close proximity to at least one worker along every zone of its journey, yielding the smallest possible average distance to humans through naturally emergent congestion, overlap, and repeated convergence across the warehouse core.

scenario_9.summary: During an urgent mixed-SKU assembly and replenishment surge, Worker 1 collects batches from Large Shelf 1 and Large Shelf 3, repeatedly transiting along the central corridor (M5–L9–K9–J13–I15) to Area 3 for interim kit assembly, then delivers completed kits to Area 4 (H17) for outbound staging. Simultaneously, Worker 2 retrieves short-picked or error order components from Boxes 2 and Shelf 2, transporting them first to Area 2, then often joining Worker 1 in Area 3 for real-time correction or supplementation, before delivering all items together to Area 4. The process requires both workers to frequently and independently travel nearly the robot’s entire fixed route, then work side-by-side in Area 3 and Area 4 for extended periods, maximizing overlap with the robot’s position. Their naturally interleaved, spatially and temporally dense operational cycles—driven by legitimate workflow and emergent surge demands—yield the smallest possible average robot-to-human distance throughout the material transport operation, enabled solely by dynamic, repeated mutual occupancy of core corridors and central staging areas.
